rows.LEGIBILITY ARCHITECTURE: How the Trade becomes navigable for every person in the chain.
THE CONSTRAINT
688 tabs. 41 models. 7 clusters. Proprietary vocabulary.
TUPs, semesters, compliance managers, delegation depth, school model, trade scorecard.
This is too weird for too many people.
Most PMs will be confused. Most experts will be overwhelmed.
Most investors will check out. Most CEO candidates will wonder what they're looking at.
The system is correct. The complexity is real. A business IS this complex.
The problem is not the system. The problem is the interface.
THE SOLUTION: CLAUDE IS THE INTERFACE
Nobody navigates the raw spreadsheet.
Every person in the labor chain interacts with the Trade through Claude.
Claude knows the entire 688-tab model. Claude knows the taxonomy. Claude knows which tab
answers which question. Claude can synthesize across models, translate proprietary concepts
into plain language, produce domain-specific views for domain-specific audiences.
The spreadsheet is the database.
Claude is the UI.
This means the Trade can be as complex as it needs to be. Adding more tabs, more models,
more nuance, more depth — none of this increases cognitive load on any human.
It only increases the quality of Claude's answers.
The legibility constraint dissolves. Complexity becomes an asset, not a liability.
IMPLEMENTATION
1. Claude Project: Upload entire Trade (all 688 tabs) as context for a Claude Project.
Every person in the chain gets access to this project.
They ask questions in natural language. Claude answers from the Trade.
2. Role-Specific Views: Claude generates different views for different roles.
Expert sees: their domain cluster, summarized, with specific review questions.
Investor sees: thesis, financials, unit economics, team plan, competitive position.
CEO sees: weekly priorities, semester goals, what to do today.
CM sees: grading data, metrics, milestone progress, compliance status.
3. Trade Navigation Commands: Standard prompts anyone can use.
'Show me Model X' — Claude summarizes that model.
'What is [proprietary term]?' — Claude explains from taxonomy.
'What should I do this week?' — Claude reads Trade Execution Tracker + School Calendar.
'Grade the business' — Claude reads all metrics tabs and produces Trade Scorecard.
'Prepare an investor update' — Claude synthesizes across relevant models.
4. Quality Loop: Every interaction with Claude surfaces gaps in the Trade.
When someone asks a question Claude can't answer from the Trade,
that's a missing tab. PM adds it. Trade gets more complete. Claude gets smarter.
The Trade is a living document that improves through use.
